description: From Latin deliberatus, past participle of delibero (“I consider, weigh well”), from de + *libero, libro (“I weigh”), from *libera, libra (“a balance”); see librate.

adjectives.description: deliberate (comparative more deliberate, superlative most deliberate)

examples: Tripping me was a deliberate action.
Synonyms: purposeful, volitional; see also Thesaurus:intentional

entries.meaning: Formed with deliberation; carefully considered; not sudden or rash.
examples: a deliberate opinion; a deliberate measure or result
Synonyms: careful, cautious, well-advised; see also Thesaurus:cautious

entries.meaning: Of a person, weighing facts and arguments with a view to a choice or decision; carefully considering the probable consequences of a step; slow in determining.
examples: The jury took eight hours to come to its deliberate verdict.

verbs.description: deliberate (third-person singular simple present deliberates, present participle deliberating, simple past and past participle deliberated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To consider carefully; to weigh well in the mind.
examples: It is now time for the jury to deliberate the guilt of the defendant.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To consider the reasons for and against anything; to reflect.
